description: 2020 JUN 05-- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News-- Investigators publish new report on Conservation Research. Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration,“ Motivated by recent developments in image recognition, we hosted a data science challenge on the crowdsourcing...
text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily
News \-- Investigators publish new report on Conservation Research. According
to news reporting out of Woods Hole, Massachusetts, by NewsRx editors,
research stated, "Photo identification is an important tool for estimating
abundance and monitoring population trends over time. However, manually
matching photographs to known individuals is time-consuming."

Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from National Oceanic
and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), "Motivated by recent developments in
image recognition, we hosted a data science challenge on the crowdsourcing
platform Kaggle to automate the identification of endangered North Atlantic
right whales (Eubalaena glacialis). The winning solution automatically
identified individual whales with 87% accuracy with a series of convolutional
neural networks to identify the region of interest on an image, rotate, crop,
and create standardized photographs of uniform size and orientation and then
identify the correct individual whale from these passport-like photographs.
Recent advances in deep learning coupled with this fully automated workflow
have yielded impressive results and have the potential to revolutionize
traditional methods for the collection of data on the abundance and
distribution of wild populations."

According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Presenting these
results to a broad audience should further bridge the gap between the data
science and conservation science communities."

For more information on this research see: Applying deep learning to right
whale photo identification. _Conservation Biology_ , 2019;33(3):676-684.
_Conservation Biology_ can be contacted at: Wiley, 111 River St, Hoboken
07030-5774, NJ, USA. (Wiley-Blackwell - <http://www.wiley.com/>; Conservation
Biology - <http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1111/(ISSN)1523-1739>)

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting C.B. Khan, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA),
National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Woods Hole, MA 02543, United
States. Additional authors for this research include R. Bogucki, M. Klimek,
J.K. Milczek, M. Cygan and M. Mucha.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1111/cobi.13226>. This DOI is a link to an online
electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your
direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Studies from National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Provide New Data on Conservation Research (Applying deep learning to right whale photo identification): Conservation Research
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- Investigators publish new report on Conservation Research. According to news reporting out of Woods Hole, Massachusetts, by NewsRx editors, research stated, “Photo identification is an important tool for estimating abundance and monitoring population trends over time. However, manually matching photographs to known individuals is time-consuming.”

Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), “Motivated by recent developments in image recognition, we hosted a data science challenge on the crowdsourcing platform Kaggle to automate the identification of endangered North Atlantic right whales (Eubalaena glacialis). The winning solution automatically identified individual whales with 87% accuracy with a series of convolutional neural networks to identify the region of interest on an image, rotate, crop, and create standardized photographs of uniform size and orientation and then identify the correct individual whale from these passport-like photographs. Recent advances in deep learning coupled with this fully automated workflow have yielded impressive results and have the potential to revolutionize traditional methods for the collection of data on the abundance and distribution of wild populations.”

According to the news editors, the research concluded: “Presenting these results to a broad audience should further bridge the gap between the data science and conservation science communities.”

For more information on this research see: Applying deep learning to right whale photo identification. Conservation Biology, 2019;33(3):676-684. Conservation Biology can be contacted at: Wiley, 111 River St, Hoboken 07030-5774, NJ, USA. (Wiley-Blackwell - http://www.wiley.com/; Conservation Biology - http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1111/(ISSN)1523-1739)

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting C.B. Khan, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Woods Hole, MA 02543, United States. Additional authors for this research include R. Bogucki, M. Klimek, J.K. Milczek, M. Cygan and M. Mucha.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1111/cobi.13226. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
